chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The OMNeT++ simulation IDE is based on the Eclipse Framework, for which manuals are available on www.eclipse.org. While this flexible and easy to use platform makes the OMNeT++ simulation IDE inherently more easy to use, it helps to have a concise reference on what the system is capable of and just how you can reach the appropriate section. In developing the OMNeT++ IDE, we followed guidelines for making Eclipse plugins, integrating the functionality available in separate modules in OMNeT++ 3.3 into one comprehensive system. This approach has many benefits. The environment will be instantly recognizable to those at home with the Eclipse system, but sections will also become quickly familiar to users of earlier versions of OMNeT++. Having the system's functions interconnected this way brings more power and flexibility to the system.

The OMNeT++ 4.0 Integrated Development Environment extends Eclipse with new editors, views, wizards, and other functionality. OMNeT++ adds functionality for creating and configuring models (NED and .ini files), performing batch executions and analyzing the simulation results, while Eclipse provides C++ editing, CVS/SVN integration and optionally other features (UML modeling, bug-tracker integration, database access, etc) via various open-source and commercial plug-ins.

sect1.title: The Workbench
sect1.para: The Eclipse Editor layout consists of various Views and Editors. These are collected into Perspectives that define which Views and Editors are visible, and how they are sized and positioned.

Eclipse is a very flexible system. You can move, resize, hide and show various panels, editors and navigators. This allows you to customize the IDE to your liking, but it also makes it more difficult to describe. First, we need to make sure that we are looking at the same thing.

sect1.picture: Selecting the OMNeT++ perspective in Eclipse
sect1.para: Most interface elements within Eclipse are movable, can be docked to various palettes or sections. The whole workspace is configurable, so you can construct your own workspace, but we will use the following layout throughout this manual, to get familiar with the various sections:
sect1.picture: OMNeT++ IDE with README.txt selected in the Navigator
sect1.para: The Navigator on the top left part of the screen shows a hierarchical view of the various open projects in your workspace. In the example above, the "aloha" demo project is open, you can see the various .NED, .ini and other files inside.

We double-clicked the README.txt file, and its contents are loaded into the editor area. Eclipse automatically launches the editor associated with a particular file type, so you can start editing right away.

This view contains information on the particular object that is selected.in the editor area, or one of the other views that serve as a selection provider. In case of NED objects for example, display-specific properties such as icons, colorization, position, etc. Can be read and set here. Help is also available in the form of code assist, where pressing CTRL+SPACE in one of the fields will provide you with a list of selectable valid options for that field. Some fields, such as the Icon property, or Color type properties have graphical picker dialogs associated with them too.

A number of views are docked here. The Problems View references code lines where Eclipse encountered a problem while parsing. The Editor also provides visual feedback by placing a red "X" icon in front of the line of code that is causing the problem.
The Module Hierarchy View will show you what modules are nested in the currently selected NED object.
The NED Parameters View lists all the parameters defined inside the selected object, as well as the parameters that the object inherited from other objects.
The Debug View contains debug output. This is a standard Eclipse feature.
The Console View is where all console output will be redirected to, if you run a simulation from within Eclipse.
The Event Log View will show you a list of events for a simulation that has been executed.
